Now I’ve taken 200 grams of onion, finely chopped. After 30 minutes, we’ll start making the biryani. Half an hour is up. On high flame, I’ve placed the cooker and added 250 ml of oil.

While the mutton is cooking, we’ll boil the rice. It’s been 30 minutes since soaking. In a large pot, I’ve taken 3–4 liters of water. I’m adding 3–4 tablespoons of salt — as per the water amount.
Now I’ll add some whole spices: 2 bay leaves, 1 tsp black pepper, 6 small cardamoms, 1 tsp fennel seeds, 1 tsp shah jeera (caraway), 2 black cardamoms, 2 star anise, and 6–7 cloves.
We’ll wait for the water to boil. As you can see, the soaked rice has puffed up — it has absorbed water and will now cook faster when boiled.

If you get whole spices in your bite while eating, it’s not pleasant. So strain the water — all the flavors have transferred into it. Now I’m adding the rice. What do we need to do with the rice?
I’ve added all the rice. Turn the flame to high. Stir it gently once to ensure rice doesn’t settle at the bottom. Let it cook on high flame for 3–4 minutes. Cooking time depends on the rice variety.

You can see how long the rice has become — it has almost doubled in size. That’s why soaking for 30 minutes is crucial. As you can see, the grains are fluffy and separate — we didn’t even add lemon juice.
We had already added kewra water to the potatoes. So they carry that flavor.
Let’s now start assembling the biryani for dum. I’ve taken a vessel — first I’ll add a little oil (rogan). Then a layer of rice. The remaining rice will be added later — this is our first layer.

Add 1 cup of milk. You can use mawa (milk solids) too, or even both. Kolkata biryani traditionally uses mawa. Now I’m adding a bit of the reserved rogan (flavored oil) again.
Finally, add 2 to 3 tablespoons of ghee. You *must* add ghee at the end — it gives the biryani a great aroma and adds shine to the rice.
